declarations.comments:
Monad handling pool resource acquisition & release

```
runPostgres
  {connectionString: "postgresql://postgres:postgres@localhost:5432"}
  $ session do
      exec_ "create table foo (bar int);"
      exec_ "insert into foo values (1);"
      res <- query "select * from foo"
      pure $ res == 1
```

Is equivalent to:
```
do
  pool <- liftEffect $ Pool.make {connectionString: "postgresql://postgres:postgres@localhost:5432"}
  finally (Pool.end pool) do
    client <- Pool.connect pool
    finally (liftEffect $ Pool.release pool client) do
      Client.exec_ "create table foo (bar int);" client
      Client.exec_ "insert into foo values (1);" client
      res <- Client.query "select * from foo" client
      pure $ res == 1
```
declarations.title: PostgresT

declarations.comments:
Lifts a session to `PostgresT`, running the session
in a transaction.

If the session throws an error, the transaction will be
rolled back and the error rethrown.
declarations.title: transaction

declarations.comments:
Lifts a session to `PostgresT`, releasing the client to the pool
after execution.
declarations.title: session

declarations.comments:
Create a new connection pool from the provided config and execute
the postgres monad, invoking `Effect.Aff.Postgres.Pool.end` afterwards.
declarations.title: runPostgres

children.comments: Fetch a specified number of rows from the cursor
children.title: fetch

children.comments: Fetch all remaining rows from the cursor
children.title: fetchAll

declarations.comments:
A monad representing a handle to a server-side cursor

```
runPostgres {connectionString: "..."} do
  exec_ "create table foo (id int not null primary key);"
  exec_
    $ intercalate "\n "
      [ "insert into foo (id)"
      , "values"
      , intercalate ", "
          $ map (\n -> "(" <> show n <> ")")
          $ Array.range 1 100
      ]

  cursor @Int "foo_cursor" "select id from foo" do
    a <- fetchOne -- 1
    b <- fetchOne -- 2
    c <- fetchOne -- 3
    d <- fetch 10 -- 4..14
    e <- fetchAll -- 15..100
    pure unit
```
declarations.title: MonadCursor

declarations.comments: Fetch the next row from the cursor
declarations.title: fetchOne

declarations.comments:
Create a server-side cursor for a query in a transaction,
and execute a `CursorT` with a view to the new cursor.
declarations.title: cursor

children.comments: Executes a query and unmarshals the result into `r`
children.title: query

children.comments: Executes a query and returns the number of rows affected
children.title: exec

children.comments: Executes a query and discards the result
children.title: exec_

declarations.comments:
Monad handling pool resource acquisition & release

```
runPostgres
  {connectionString: "postgresql://postgres:postgres@localhost:5432"}
  $ session do
      exec_ "create table foo (bar int);"
      exec_ "insert into foo values (1);"
      res <- query "select * from foo"
      pure $ res == 1
```

Is equivalent to:
```
do
  pool <- liftEffect $ Pool.make {connectionString: "postgresql://postgres:postgres@localhost:5432"}
  finally (Pool.end pool) do
    client <- Pool.connect pool
    finally (liftEffect $ Pool.release pool client) do
      Client.exec_ "create table foo (bar int);" client
      Client.exec_ "insert into foo values (1);" client
      res <- Client.query "select * from foo" client
      pure $ res == 1
```

declarations.comments: A monad representing a connected session to a database

declarations.comments: Newtype hinting that this value should be serialized / deserialized as a JSON string.
declarations.title: JSON

declarations.comments:
This mutates `import('pg').types`, setting deserialization
for some types to unmarshal as strings rather than JS values.
declarations.title: modifyPgTypes

declarations.comments: Serialize data of type `a` to a `Raw` SQL value.
declarations.title: Serialize

declarations.comments: Deserialize data of type `a` from a `Raw` SQL value.
declarations.title: Deserialize

declarations.comments: A type which is `Rep`resentable as a SQL value.
declarations.title: Rep

declarations.comments:
Coerces the value to `Raw`.

This is only safe for values whose javascript representation
can be directly serialized by `node-postgres` to the corresponding
SQL type.
declarations.title: unsafeSerializeCoerce

declarations.comments:
SQL Query

* `text` - the query string
* `values` - query parameter values
* `name` (optional) - providing this will create this query as a [prepared statement](https://node-postgres.com/features/queries#prepared-statements)
declarations.title: Query

declarations.comments: Values that can be rendered as a SQL query
declarations.title: AsQuery

declarations.comments:
Monad for building parameterized queries without managing positional
parameters directly

For example, given the table `CREATE TABLE foo (id INT NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY, bar TEXT NOT NULL)`

```purescript
updateFoo :: Int -> String -> Effect Query
updateFoo id newBar =
  build do
    idP <- param id
    newBarP <- param newBar
    pure $
      [ "update foo"
      , "set bar = " <> newBarP
      , "where id = " <> idP
      ]
```
`updateFoo 1 "test"` will yield:
```purescript
{ text: "update foo\nset bar = $2\nwhere id = $1"
, values: ["test", 1]
}
```
declarations.title: QueryBuilderT

declarations.comments:
Yields a SQL string referencing the last parameter in the parameter list

Examples:
- if no parameters have been appended this will yield `"$0"` (invalid)
- if 1 parameter has been appended this will yield `"$1"`
- if 5 parameters have been appended this will yield `"$5"`
declarations.title: lastParamString

declarations.comments: Append a serializable SQL value to the parameter list
declarations.title: appendParam

declarations.comments: Replace the builder's query string with a new value
declarations.title: putText

declarations.comments:
Adds a parameter to the query

This accepts any value `Rep`resentable in SQL, and
yields the SQL string for the new parameter.

```purescript
do
  p1 <- param 1     -- "$1"
  p2 <- param "foo" -- "$2"
  p3 <- param true  -- "$3"
  pure unit
```
declarations.title: param

declarations.comments:
Accepts a `QueryBuilder` monad that yields the built query string
and yields the finished `Query`.

```
build $ pure "select 1"
-- Query {text: "select 1", values: [], name: Nothing}
```
 
```
build do
  foo <- param "foo"
  pure $ "select " <> foo
-- Query {text: "select $1", values: ["foo"], name: Nothing}
```
declarations.title: build

declarations.comments:
A range of values with optional upper & lower bounds.

* `mempty -> '(,)'`
* `gte 1 -> '[1,)'`
* `lt 2 -> '(,2]'`
* `gte 1 <> lt 2 -> '[1,2)'`
declarations.title: Range

declarations.comments: An upper or lower range bound
declarations.title: Bound

declarations.comments: Get the value of the bound
declarations.title: boundValue

declarations.comments: Whether this bound includes the value `a`
declarations.title: boundIsInclusive

declarations.comments: The upper bound of a range
declarations.title: upper

declarations.comments: The lower bound of a range
declarations.title: lower

declarations.comments:
Creates a bound from a bool indicating if the bound is inclusive
and a value `a`
declarations.title: makeBound

declarations.comments: Returns whether the range contains value `a`
declarations.title: contains

declarations.comments: Creates a range with no upper bound and inclusive lower bound `a`; `[a,)`
declarations.title: gte

declarations.comments: Creates a range with no upper bound and exclusive lower bound `a`; `(a,)`
declarations.title: gt

declarations.comments: Creates a range with no lower bound and inclusive upper bound `a`; `(,a]`
declarations.title: lt

declarations.comments: Creates a range with no lower bound and exclusive upper bound `a`; `(,a)`
declarations.title: lte

contents.contents: `Eq Raw` only checks equality for JS primitives, and is always `false` for objects.

declarations.comments:
A raw JS value converted from SQL

In practice, this is an alias for `Foreign` with
type system guarantees that purescript types are
correctly represented in JS to be represented in SQL.
declarations.title: Raw

declarations.comments:
Stringifies a `Raw` value if a JS primitive,
else returns a debug representation.

* `{foo: 'bar'} -> "[Object]"`
* `[1, 2, 3] -> "[Array]"`
* `'foo' -> "foo"`
* `123 -> "123"`
declarations.title: rawToDebugString

declarations.comments:
Performs JS referential equality `===` for primitives
or arrays of primitives, else returns `false`.
declarations.title: rawDebugEq

declarations.comments:
Coerce a `Foreign` value to `Raw`.

This is only safe if the `Foreign` value
is guaranteed to be serializable to a SQL
value via `pg-types`.
declarations.title: unsafeFromForeign

declarations.comments:
Returns the number of rows affected by the query

<https://node-postgres.com/apis/result#resultrowcount-int--null>
declarations.title: rowsAffected

children.comments: Minimum length of row for type `a`
children.title: minColumnCount

declarations.comments:
Can be unmarshalled from a queried row

Implementations are provided for:
 * tuples of any length containing types that are `Rep`
 * tuples of any length with the last member of `Array Raw`
 * a single value of a type that is `Rep`
 * `Array Raw`
 * `Unit` (always succeeds)

```
-- CREATE TABLE foo
--   ( id INT NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY
--   , fruit TEXT NOT NULL
--   , created TIMESTAMPTZ NOT NULL DEFAULT NOW()
--   );
do
  let q = query "select id, fruit, created from foo" client

  -- pick all 3 columns explicitly
  _ :: Array (Int /\ String /\ DateTime) <- q

  -- pick first 2 columns, discarding any others
  _ :: Array (Int /\ String) <- q

  -- pick first 2 columns, if any more keep as `Array Raw`
  _ :: Array (Int /\ String /\ Array Raw) <- q

  -- pick just the ID, discarding all other columns
  id :: Array Int <- q

  pure unit
```
declarations.title: FromRow

declarations.comments:
Create a client and immediately connect it to the database

The config parameter `r` is `Config` with all keys optional.

This is a shorthand for `(voidRight <*> connect) =<< liftEffect (make cfg)`
declarations.title: connected

declarations.comments:
Connects the client to the database

<https://node-postgres.com/apis/client#clientconnect>
declarations.title: connect

declarations.comments:
Disconnects the client from the database

<https://node-postgres.com/apis/client#clientend>
declarations.title: end

declarations.comments:
Performs a query that we expect to not yield any rows,
returning the number of rows affected by the statement.

<https://node-postgres.com/apis/client#clientquery>
declarations.title: exec

declarations.comments:
Performs a query that we expect to yield rows,
returning them unmarshalled into destination type `r`.

<https://node-postgres.com/apis/client#clientquery>
declarations.title: query

declarations.comments:
Performs a query, returning the raw `Result` object

<https://node-postgres.com/apis/client#clientquery>
declarations.title: queryRaw

declarations.comments:
Creates a new client, not yet connected to the database.

The config parameter `r` is `Config` with all keys optional.

<https://node-postgres.com/apis/client#new-client>
declarations.title: make

declarations.comments:
Acquires a client from the pool.

 * If there are idle clients in the pool one will be returned to the callback on process.nextTick.
 * If the pool is not full but all current clients are checked out a new client will be created & returned to this callback.
 * If the pool is 'full' and all clients are currently checked out will wait in a FIFO queue until a client becomes available by it being released back to the pool.

<https://node-postgres.com/apis/pool#poolconnect>
declarations.title: connect

declarations.comments:
Drain the pool of all active clients, disconnect them,
and shut down any internal timers in the pool.

It is common to call this at the end of a script using the pool or when
your process is attempting to shut down cleanly.

<https://node-postgres.com/apis/pool#poolend>
declarations.title: end

declarations.comments:
Pool construction config

Includes all Client config options
declarations.title: Config

declarations.comments:
Creates a new pool

The config parameter `r` is `Config` with all keys optional.

<https://node-postgres.com/apis/pool#new-pool>
declarations.title: make

declarations.comments:
The number of queued requests waiting on a client when all clients are checked out.
It can be helpful to monitor this number to see if you need to adjust the size of the pool.
declarations.title: clientWaitingCount

declarations.comments: The number of clients which are not checked out but are currently idle in the pool.
declarations.title: clientIdleCount

declarations.comments: The total number of clients existing within the pool.
declarations.title: clientCount

declarations.comments:
FFI binding to `Client#release` for clients created from pools

Accepts a `Pool` as a type-level hint that the `Client` should have
come from a `Pool`
declarations.title: __release

declarations.comments:
Creates a new client, not yet connected to the database.

The config parameter `r` is `Config` with all keys optional.

declarations.comments:
Pool construction config

Includes all Client config options

declarations.title: clientCount

declarations.title: clientIdleCount

declarations.comments:
The number of queued requests waiting on a client when all clients are checked out.
It can be helpful to monitor this number to see if you need to adjust the size of the pool.

Creates a new pool
